title: What is the best music player for Windows? - Quora

response.answer_text: Depends on what you are playing or streaming. And are you already paying for a subscription service? If so, that’s your answer, right? Anyway starting there - I assume the two most popular are Spotify and iTunes. I used Spotify for years and mostly loved it. I finally gave in and switched to Apple Music because of integration issues with my iOS devices. And actually I’m a fan of the Apple Music app on my iPhone & iPad - but iTunes for Windows is a pain and slow. It’s usable - just clunky - I can’t help think it’s at least partly due to the ongoing “apple vs. microsoft” feud bullshit. To answer you question though - I’ve used the following player for Windows for over 15 years. (since it was called media jukebox) JRiver Media Center I’ve tried tons of them and this, for me, is hands down the best. At least it was - or is for now - but it’s for large collections of LOCAL music files (mp3 or whatever format) - it’s not for streaming. At least not with the big players - no spotify or apple music (iTunes). Which seems like a dead man walking… I still use it because I have a huge collection of mp3 files that i’ve meticulously nurtured for decades and i’m reluctant to abandoned it. (iTunes match at least let me sync/upload those files which worked okay. It doesn’t organize things the way I like but it’s alright. Spotify didn’t offer anything like that.) Finally - JRMC does a lot more than I use it for - it’s a full on media player - i just don’t use it for anything but music. Oh and I recently got their app for iOS which allows me to stream my music library from my Windows desktop to my iOS devices which is awesome. Anyway - there are tons of decent players for Windows out there - the best one for you? Hard to say… This looks very interesting (but way spendy!)Roon Labs Community And here’s a bunch of info:Comparison of audio player software - Wikipedia Good luck!

As much as I HATE ITunes, it might be, to me the best music player for Windows. But not for the most obvious reasons. It can scan your whole computer and organize your music pretty Accurately. It'll place songs that either just have an artist name or title in the correct place and make things so much easier. Ive used Groove Music, but it's organization sucks! VLC Player had always been great. It's ability to play many different audio files no matter the distinction places it in the must have app slot, but to me the sound suffers a bit. Especially since it comes with its own volume control (which was set on max when I recently downloaded it and all I could here was distortion hell coming from my speakers.) Now, like I said iTunes has many flaws. Constant updates, a need to be signed in to access purchased music, internet access to get proper album covers. The list goes on. Don't even get me started on the sound quality! Once imported a project of mine that was all wav files and they sounded horrible the way iTunes read them. But the organization is superb. And if you're just looking to zone out to music as a background who cares for the sound quality that much?
